title: Longtime Fox News Host Alan Colmes Dies At 66
text:
Longtime Fox News Host Alan Colmes Dies At 66 "... the two most fortunate men in all of television." by Jeff Neukom February 23, 2017 at 9:35am Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
Veteran Fox News commentator Alan Colmes passed away Thursday following a brief illness. He was 66. The cause of death has not yet been released. 
Colmes had been with Fox News since its inception in 1996, when then-CEO Roger Ailes asked him to join the infant network, which would soon grow to become the most watched of the cable news networks. 
With Fox, the left-learning Colmes offered an intellectual counterpunch to Sean Hannity on the Hannity & Colmes program , stepping into that role after a string of successful radio shows on WNBC, WABC and WMCA in New York City. Advertisement - story continues below Chris Wallace: Trump Press Conference Showed America He’s In Charge [WATCH] 
The two often battled point, counterpoint during the show’s 13-year run, exchanging intellectual haymakers, ducking and weaving around the poignant observations of the other. 
While the two possessed very opposite political opinions, their differences did not cause strife between them. In fact, it was quite the opposite, according to Hannity. He called their bond a “deep friendship,” offering his respects during an appearance Thursday morning on Fox News. Advertisement – story continues below 
“When Alan and I started Hannity & Colmes , there wasn’t a day that went by where we didn’t say we were the two most fortunate men in all of television,” said Hannity. 
“Alan, in the midst of great sickness and illness, showed the single greatest amount of courage I’ve ever seen,” he added. 
Colmes is survived by his wife, Dr. Jocelyn Elise Crowley, who is a professor at Rutgers University. She issued the following statement: 
Alan Colmes passed away this morning after a brief illness. He was 66-years-old. He leaves his adoring and devoted wife, Jocelyn Elise Crowley. He was a great guy, brilliant, hysterical, and moral. He was fiercely loyal, and the only thing he loved more than his work was his life with Jocelyn. He will be missed. The family has asked for privacy during this very difficult time. 
News of Colmes’ death rocked many members of the media, who offered their respects on social media. Advertisement - story continues below
